Articles.Content: Is there any reason not to set up a 3 Sat Comm Relay in a Polar Orbit?

1 hour ago, Stosh said:

Is there any reason not to set up a 3 Sat Comm Relay in a Polar Orbit? 

There's no reason why it shouldn't be possible. However, it might not be so useful for a few reasons:

1. Launch windows. Since the KSC is exactly at the equator, launching to 0 degrees is quite easy- just go East whenever you want. But when you're going polar, the KSC usually isn't under the orbital track of the target, so you have to wait until it is, or waste lots of precious plane change dV. Since you'll want your commsats to be on the same plane, launch windows might only come up once a day or less.

2. Lack of useful synchronous orbits. The main feature of Kerbin-stationary orbits in KSP is to keep a satellite over a specific spot on Kerbin throughout its orbit (as in real life). Most of the time this is KSC, after which signals are broadcast to a wider network of interplanetary satellites. This means you can only send up one satellite to ensure near-constant contact with the space center for your probes, as opposed to two or three for non-synchronous orbits. In a polar or inclined orbit, this can't be done.

3. Contact with the Mun. This one might be weaker than the rest, but in the early game or if your antenna range is limited, being on the same orbital plane as the Mun and close to Minmus's means more reliable signal and slightly improved range.

The main reason to not have 3 relay satellites in polar orbit is "less than 3 relay satellites in polar orbit is enough", 

Just for transmitting science from the surface of Mun/Minmus a single relay may be enough if one don't mind to wait for the sat to get into position.  More satellites will just increase coverage. 

So, it's a matter of how much you want the extra coverage vs how much you are willing to take the extra funds/time/effort to setup  the relays.

Personally I just complete 3-5 satellite contracts around every body, and give those satellites enough relay antennas to reach Kerbin. Then, the satellites pay for themselves (or more) and I get a relay network not just for free, but for negative funds.

Sure they're not perfectly set up (though you can move them after if you're persnickety) but in my experience 5 satellites gives coverage almost always, and those few times it doesn't I have a chance to think up a plan b.

I tend to just spam satellites in long elliptical polar orbits everywhere, it's not very efficient but it nets me coverage pretty much 100% of the time. I've experimented with stationary orbits before but it requires either extreme precision, constant stationkeeping or mods/savefile edits, so I usually don't bother.
